title: 106_hr4730
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia Recognition Act". The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, are recognized as political successors to the signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington. With over 2,500 eligible members, they chose not to be removed and continue to operate as a sovereign tribe in Georgia. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, chose to remain near their ancestral homeland in Georgia. They operate as a sovereign tribe with a viable tribal government, petitioning for Federal recognition in 1972 but facing challenges due to lack of education and legal counsel. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia faced challenges in obtaining Federal recognition due to lack of education and legal counsel. Despite the denial of their petition in 1981, they have been recognized by the Federal Government, the government of the State of Georgia, and local governments as a distinct political entity. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "member" refers to an enrolled member of the Tribe or an individual placed on the membership rolls in accordance with this Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" refers to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia. SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition is extended to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, making them eligible for federal benefits and services without the need for a reservation. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 is applicable to the Tribe and its members. SEC. 5 of the Act establishes a reservation for the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia by allowing the transfer of land to the Secretary for trust purposes. Gaming activities are prohibited on the reservation land. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL.

The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution. Future membership is limited to lineal descendants of those on the base roll who maintain political relations with the Tribe.

SEC. 7. JURISDICTION.

The reservation established by the Act falls under Federal and tribal jurisdiction.

SEC. 8. TREATIES NOT AFFECTED. The reservation established by this Act will be considered Indian country under Federal and tribal jurisdiction. This Act will not affect any treaties or rights secured to the tribes mentioned in the Act.
